Candentity.desc: FC Bayern Munich is a German sports club based in Munich, Bavaria, known for its highly successful professional football team with a record 30 national titles and 20 national cups, and a history of European success including six UEFA Champions League titles.

Candentity.name: History_of_Sevastopol
Candentity.desc: Sevastopol is the largest city in Crimea, a major port on the Black Sea, and a significant naval base with a rich history, strategic location, and a robust economy driven by its unique naval and maritime features.

Candentity.name: Russian_battleship_Sevastopol_(1911)
Candentity.desc: The Russian battleship Sevastopol was a Gangut-class dreadnought built before World War I, serving in the Imperial Russian Navy, then the Soviet Navy, and played a role in various conflicts including World War II before being broken up in 1956-1957.

Candentity.name: Theoderichshafen
Candentity.desc: Theoderichshafen is not mentioned in the provided text, but Sevastopol is a city in Crimea with a strategic location and a significant naval base, having been an important port and naval base throughout its history.

Candentity.name: Montenegro_(province)
Candentity.desc: Montenegro was a temporary province in the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes that existed from 1918 to 1922 before being abolished and replaced with new administrative units.

Candentity.name: Sevastopol,_Ukraine
Candentity.desc: Sevastopol is the largest city in Crimea, a major port on the Black Sea, and a significant naval base, with a population of 479,394 and a unique economy driven by its naval and maritime features.

Candentity.name: FC_Sevastopol

Candentity.name: Sevastopolâ
Candentity.desc: Sevastopol is the largest city on Crimea, a major port on the Black Sea, and a strategically important naval base with a Russian majority population, featuring a robust economy, mild winters, and moderate warm summers, making it a popular tourist destination and centre for marine biology research.

Candentity.name: Sevastopol,_Russia

Candentity.name: Sevastopol

Candentity.name: Northern_Rock_Foundation
Candentity.desc: The Northern Rock Foundation was a UK-based charity that aimed to tackle disadvantage and improve quality of life in the North East and Cumbria, awarding Â£235.

Candentity.name: Nationalisation_of_Northern_Rock
Candentity.desc: The Nationalisation of Northern Rock refers to the 2008 takeover of the British bank Northern Rock by the British Labour Government due to financial difficulties caused by the subprime mortgage crisis, which was later split into two parts and eventually sold to Virgin Money in 2012.

Candentity.name: Westminster_tube_station
Candentity.desc: Westminster tube station is a London Underground station in the City of Westminster, served by the Circle, District, and Jubilee lines, and located near iconic landmarks such as the Houses of Parliament, Westminster Abbey, and the London Eye.

Candentity.name: Ravenglass_and_Eskdale_Railway_locomotives
Candentity.desc: The Ravenglass and Eskdale Railway locomotives refers to the details of the locomotives used on the 15-inch narrow gauge preserved railway line that runs from Ravenglass to Dalegarth in Cumbria.

Candentity.name: Northern_rock_sole
Candentity.desc: The Northern Rock Sole is a demersal fish that inhabits the temperate waters of the northern Pacific, ranging from Puget Sound to Alaska, and can grow up to 69 cm in length with a maximum recorded lifespan of 18 years.

Candentity.name: Semibalanus_balanoides
Candentity.desc: Semibalanus balanoides is a common and widespread boreo-arctic species of acorn barnacle found on rocks and other substrates in the intertidal zone of north-western Europe and both coasts of North America.

Candentity.name: Northern_Rock
Candentity.desc: Northern Rock was a British bank that demutualized in 1997, experienced financial difficulties during the 2007-2008 global banking crisis, and was taken into public ownership in 2008 before being returned to private ownership in 2012 and eventually sold to Cerberus Capital Management in 2016.

Candentity.name: Northern_rock_mouse
Candentity.desc: The Northern Rock Mouse is a species of rodent in the family Cricetidae, found in Mexico and the United States.

Candentity.name: Landmark_Mortgages
Candentity.desc: Landmark Mortgages is a British asset holding and management company that was previously known as NRAM plc, the "bad bank" of Northern Rock, and was sold to Cerberus Capital Management in 2016, holding the bad debts of the former Northern Rock bank.

Candentity.name: North_Rock
Candentity.desc: North Rock is an offshore rock near the boundary between the Gulf of Maine and the Bay of Fundy, disputed between Canada's New Brunswick and the US state of Maine as part of the territorial and maritime boundary dispute surrounding Machias Seal Island.

Candentity.desc: Topness is a term in particle physics that refers to the property of top quarks having a value of +1 and top antiquarks having a value of -1.

Candentity.name: Torch_(browser)

Candentity.name: Canada
Candentity.desc: Canada is a country located in North America, known for its vast territory, diverse culture, and strong economy, with a parliamentary democracy and constitutional monarchy system, and is a member of several major international institutions.

Candentity.name: Culture_of_Canada
Candentity.desc: The culture of Canada is a diverse and multicultural blend of European, indigenous, and immigrant influences, shaped by its history, government policies, and institutions, which promote a progressive and inclusive society.

Candentity.name: CCGS_Hudson
Candentity.desc: CCGS Hudson is an offshore oceanographic and hydrographic survey vessel operated by the Canadian Coast Guard, which entered service in 1963 and has made several significant scientific voyages, including the first circumnavigation of the Americas in 1970.

Candentity.name: Canadian_(train)
Candentity.desc: The Canadian is a transcontinental passenger train operated by Via Rail Canada, running between Toronto and Vancouver, with a history dating back to 1955 when it was renamed from a Canadian Pacific Railway train between Toronto and Chicago.

Candentity.name: Canadian_(canoe)
Candentity.desc: The "Canadian" is a colloquial term used to describe certain types of canoes, particularly touring, whitewater, and racing canoes, which are often distinguished from kayaks in European countries.

803.mention_context: A transmission electron micrograph of influenza A virus, late passage.

Candentity.name: Influenza_C_virus
Candentity.desc: Influenza C virus is a species of the Orthomyxoviridae family that causes influenza in humans and pigs, although it is less common and severe compared to Types A and B.

Candentity.name: Influenza_A_virus_subtype_H3N8
Candentity.desc: H3N8 is a subtype of the Influenza A virus that is endemic in birds, horses, dogs, and seals, and can also infect cats experimentally, causing clinical signs and shedding of the virus.

Candentity.name: Influenza_A_virus
Candentity.desc: Influenza A virus is a negative-sense, single-stranded, segmented RNA virus that causes influenza in birds and some mammals, with various subtypes labeled according to H and N numbers and capable of mutating into different strains with varying pathogenic profiles.

Candentity.name: Influenza_A_virus_subtype_H5N6
Candentity.desc: H5N6 is a subtype of the Influenza A virus that has caused 28 human cases, including 16 fatalities, as of January 19, 2021.

Candentity.name: DNA_virus
Candentity.desc: A DNA virus is a type of virus that has a genome composed of deoxyribonucleic acid, which can be single-stranded or double-stranded, and infects both prokaryotes and eukaryotes, causing various diseases including herpes, papillomavirus, and poxvirus infections.

Candentity.name: Influenza_A_virus_subtype_H7N7
Candentity.desc: Influenza A virus subtype H7N7 is a subtype of the influenza A virus that has caused outbreaks of low and high pathogenicity in various countries, including the Netherlands, England, Spain, China, and Australia, resulting in the culling of thousands of chickens and suspension of poultry imports.

Candentity.name: Influenza_B_virus
Candentity.desc: Influenza B virus is a species of Orthomyxoviridae that infects only humans and seals, with two circulating lineages and a slower mutation rate than Influenza A virus, but can still cause significant morbidity and mortality worldwide, particularly among adolescents and schoolchildren.

Candentity.name: Influenza_A_virus_subtype_H5N2
Candentity.desc: Influenza A virus subtype H5N2 is a bird-infecting virus that can cause mild to severe illness in birds, with occasional outbreaks in poultry farms, and can also infect humans who work with birds, but with minimal health effects and no evidence of human-to-human transmission.

Candentity.name: Influenza_D_virus
Candentity.desc: Influenza D virus is a species of Orthomyxoviridae that causes influenza in pigs and cattle, but no human infections have been observed, and it is distinct from previously-known Influenzavirus C.

Candentity.name: Influenza_A_virus_subtype_H7N9
Candentity.desc: Influenza A virus subtype H7N9 is a highly pathogenic and potentially pandemic-causing virus that has a mortality rate of around 30% and has been linked to live bird markets, with a high incidence among older males.

Candentity.desc: The Large ElectronâPositron Collider was a massive particle accelerator built at CERN, colliding electrons with positrons at energies reaching 209 GeV, and was used from 1989 to 2000 before being dismantled to make way for the Large Hadron Collider.

Candentity.name: Optical_PAyload_for_Lasercomm_Science
Candentity.desc: Optical PAyload for Lasercomm Science (OPALS) is a spacecraft communication instrument developed at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory that tested laser communications technology on the International Space Station in 2014 to replace traditional radio-frequency communications and increase data downlink rates by 10-100 times.

Candentity.name: Opal
Candentity.desc: Opal is a hydrated amorphous form of silica with a water content ranging from 3-21%, occurring in various types of rocks, and classified into precious and common opal, with precious opal displaying play-of-color due to its internal structure.
